flow.context: Amy is co-owner of IOP Escapes — 64 luxury vacation rental properties on Isle of Palms, SC with a ~10-person team. She's the systems and booking leader; OwnerRez featured her in a July 2025 profile where she called it their 'operational backbone.' They publicly promise owners a manager final check before every check-in plus weekly property inspections — a crushing workload as they've grown from 48 to 64 properties in under two years with the same small crew. They're adding specialized roles (revenue, onboarding, guest relations), signaling real scaling strain. No known inspection platform — likely manual photo review or in-person walkthrough. The OwnerRez profile is the strongest hook: Amy was personally featured and clearly cares about systems and tooling.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER
gatekeeper.say: Hey, could you get me through to Amy? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Don't volunteer more. Sound like you know her — casual, brief. If Amy picks up directly, jump straight to opener.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER ASKS WHY
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other vacation rental managers down in the Charleston area. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still no pitch. Dose info bit by bit. If they push harder, go to social proof. Always end with a redirect question.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally — we help a few property management companies with their inspection workflows. I actually sent Amy a note, was just following up. Would you mind giving her a heads up that Sam Parks from RapidEye called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Last attempt. If they won't transfer, get a callback window or leave a message. Do NOT fight the gatekeeper — they'll remember you next time.

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: LEAVE MESSAGE
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: That'd be great — just Sam Parks, RapidEye, and she can reach me at my cell. Is there a better time to try her — mornings or afternoons usually?
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Get a callback window so your next dial is better timed. Write down the gatekeeper's name for next call — use it to build rapport.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Amy — I work with a few other vacation rental operators in the Charleston area, actually came across the OwnerRez profile they did on you guys. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye — have you heard my name tossed around?
opener.note: Referencing the OwnerRez profile shows you live in her world — not a random dialer. Relaxed tone, feet on the desk. Don't rush past 'have you heard my name' — let her answer.

branches.label: I'm really busy / not a good time

no_not_heard.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
no_not_heard.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is —
no_not_heard.note: Self-deprecating and quick. Don't linger. Transition right into pain trigger with zero gap.

yes_heard.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
yes_heard.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
yes_heard.note: Let them talk. Whatever they say, build on it. Don't correct — bridge into discovery or pain depending on what they share.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow, maybe first thing in the morning?
bad_timing.note: Propose a specific time. If she gives you one, write it down and call back exactly then. Don't try to squeeze a pitch in.

branches.label: Just tell me what it's about quickly

reschedule_confirmed.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
reschedule_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Appreciate it, Amy.
reschedule_confirmed.note: Write down the exact time. When you call back open with: 'Hey Amy, you told me to try you back around now — it's Sam Parks.'

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
permission_fallback.note: Disarming honesty. Acknowledging it's a cold call actually lowers their guard. Most people grant 30 seconds.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is this just not something you're focused on right now?
permission_rejected.note: Split the rejection. 'Horrible time' reopens the door for a callback. 'Not focused on it' gives you intel and an exit.

branches.label: Bad timing — call me another time

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I work with another vacation rental operator on the coast — pretty similar to you guys. Luxury portfolio, around 60 homes, small team. They'd made the same promise to their owners — a manager personally checks every property before each guest walks in. And that worked great at 30 properties. But once they pushed past 50, their managers were spending entire days driving between units, eyeballing towel counts and grill covers and coffee makers — and stuff was still slipping through. Guest checks in, finds a cracked patio door nobody caught, and suddenly that 4.9 rating takes a hit on something totally preventable.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE HERE. Let the silence do the work. Amy will recognize her own reality — they literally promise manager final checks and weekly inspections across 64 properties with 10 people. Do NOT rush to the solution.

branches.label: Yeah, that sounds familiar / we deal with that
How do you solve that? / What do you do?
We actually handle that pretty well
Not really a problem for us / not interested

warm_response.label: THEY FEEL THE PAIN
warm_response.say: Yeah — so we built an AI that looks at the turnover photos your team's already taking and flags damage, missing items, staging issues — automatically, before the guest walks in. Would you be open to taking a look sometime when I'm not ambushing you on a cold call?
warm_response.note: One sentence on the solution, then CTA. Don't oversell. If she says yes, book immediately. If she wants to talk more, shift to discovery.

branches.label: Tell me more / how does it work?
We're not really looking for anything new

solution_bridge.label: THEY ASKED HOW
solution_bridge.say: We built an AI that analyzes the turnover photos your team's already taking — flags damage, missing items, staging issues, anything that's off — automatically, before the guest walks in. Plugs right into your existing workflow, no changes for your cleaners or inspectors.
solution_bridge.note: She asked, so give her the answer — but keep it tight. One breath. Then pivot to discovery or CTA. Don't dump features.

branches.label: I'm not sure we need that

warm_discovery.label: DISCOVERY — STOP PITCHING
warm_discovery.say: Love to learn more about how you guys actually do it — with 64 properties and that commitment to a manager check before every check-in, what does your inspection process look like day to day? Are your cleaners sending photos, or is it more of an in-person walkthrough thing?
warm_discovery.note: You're in discovery now. Listen more than you talk. Amy is systems-oriented so she'll likely describe the workflow in detail. Take notes on what tool they use (or don't) for photos. If she mentions Jeremy or Trish owning this, that's a referral path.

branches.label: We use a tool for that
It's been a challenge as we've grown

discovery_manual_pain.label: MANUAL PROCESS — DIG DEEPER
discovery_manual_pain.say: Got it — so someone on the team is reviewing all those photos manually before check-in? How long does that usually take per property, and who's the one actually doing it?
discovery_manual_pain.note: You're building the case that this is a time sink. If she says 'me' or 'our managers,' that's your champion. If it's a coordinator, that's useful too — learn the name.

branches.label: It takes too long / we miss stuff
We don't review photos — more in-person checks

discovery_existing_tool.label: THEY HAVE A TOOL
discovery_existing_tool.say: Oh nice — what are you using? I'm just curious because I talk to operators all day and everyone's setup is a little different.
discovery_existing_tool.note: Find out the tool. If Breezeway or similar, the gap is usually: tools collect photos but nobody reviews them fast enough. RapidEye is the brain that actually analyzes what's in the photos.

discovery_scaling_pain.label: SCALING PAIN — LEAN IN
discovery_scaling_pain.say: I bet — going from 48 to 64 properties in a couple years while keeping that gold standard promise isn't easy with ten people. What's been the biggest bottleneck — is it the inspection side, or more on the maintenance and vendor coordination?
discovery_scaling_pain.note: Shows homework without being creepy — 48-to-64 growth and team of 10 are both public. Let her vent. Whatever she says, tie it back to how RapidEye reduces the load.

branches.label: Honestly it's a little bit of everything

ownerrez_integration.label: OWNERREZ QUESTION
ownerrez_integration.say: Great question — we're built to plug into whatever system you're already running. I know you guys are deep in OwnerRez for basically everything. We'd pull reservation data and property info from there and layer the inspection intelligence on top — nothing changes for your team's workflow.
ownerrez_integration.note: Amy cares deeply about systems integration — OwnerRez is her 'operational backbone.' Don't overpromise on specifics you can't deliver. Pivot to the meeting for a proper walkthrough.

branches.label: That'd be key for us / sounds good
Tell me more about the integration
We're pretty set with our current setup

pitch_fit.label: PITCH THE FIT
pitch_fit.say: That's exactly the gap we fill. Your cleaners or inspectors take photos the same way they already do, they flow through your system, and our AI reviews every single one before the guest arrives. It catches stuff a human scrolling through 200 photos at 5 PM would miss — a stain on a couch cushion, a missing remote, a towel count that's off. No new app for your team, no workflow change.
pitch_fit.note: Tie it directly to what she just told you about their process. Then go for the meeting — don't keep selling.

branches.label: I'd need to think about it / talk to the team

pitch_fit_walkthrough.label: VIDEO WALKTHROUGH ANGLE
pitch_fit_walkthrough.say: Interesting — so your managers are physically walking every unit. That's the gold standard, but I bet it takes a ton of time across 64 properties. One thing we've been doing with operators like you is analyzing quick video walkthroughs — your manager walks through with their phone recording, and our AI compares it against the baseline. Catches anything that changed — damage, missing furniture, staging that's off. Basically gives your managers superpowers without adding any time to their day.
pitch_fit_walkthrough.note: This is the video walkthrough workflow — natural fit for teams doing in-person checks. It doesn't replace their managers, it makes them more effective.

branches.label: How does the video thing actually work?
We're fine with our current process

not_interested_objection.label: NOT INTERESTED — AGREE FIRST
not_interested_objection.say: Totally get it — I should have assumed you'd be all set. I mean, otherwise you probably would have reached out yourself, right?
not_interested_objection.note: Agree. Don't push back. This surprises them — they expect resistance. Then move to split the objection.

branches.label: They soften or laugh a little

not_interested_split.label: SPLIT THE OBJECTION
not_interested_split.say: Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that inspections aren't really a pain point for you right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Honestly, I get both.
not_interested_split.note: Binary split. If it's the cold call, she might be open to a different channel. If it's genuinely not a pain point, offer value and move to graceful exit.

branches.label: It's the cold call / I'm just busy
We really are all set on inspections
Actually, it is kind of a pain point...

have_a_process_objection.label: HAVE A PROCESS — AGREE FIRST
have_a_process_objection.say: That makes total sense — with 64 properties and the reputation you guys have built, you'd have to have something solid in place.
have_a_process_objection.note: Validate their process. Don't attack it. Then move to split to understand if they're truly happy or just resistant to change during a cold call.

have_a_process_split.label: SPLIT — PROCESS OBJECTION
have_a_process_split.say: Just curious — is it that you're fully covered and love what you've got, or is it more that switching anything right now would be a headache?
have_a_process_split.note: If it's the switching headache, that's your wedge — RapidEye layers on top of existing workflows, no migration required. If they're truly happy, offer value and exit clean.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have
Switching is the issue / too busy to change
It's not perfect but it works

sell_test_drive_no_switch.label: NO SWITCHING NEEDED
sell_test_drive_no_switch.say: Totally fair — and honestly that's the thing, we're not a replacement for anything you're doing. We layer on top. Your cleaners keep taking photos the same way, your managers keep doing their checks — we just catch the stuff that slips through before the guest does. No new app, no training, no migration. Would you be open to just seeing what it looks like? Fifteen minutes, worst case you see what other coastal operators are doing and steal some ideas.
sell_test_drive_no_switch.note: The 'no workflow change' message is critical for Amy — she built their entire tech stack around OwnerRez and doesn't want disruption. Emphasize it layers on top.

branches.label: OK, I could look at it

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally respect that. Look — you're probably not buying anything on a cold call, and I wouldn't expect you to. But the operators who end up in the best spot are the ones who already know what's out there when they do have bandwidth. Would you be open to fifteen minutes, no pressure? If nothing else, I can walk you through what other luxury PM companies in your market are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
sell_test_drive.note: Low pressure. Future-pacing. The 'steal some ideas' angle works well with operators who pride themselves on being best-in-class — and IOP Escapes calls themselves the 'gold standard.'

value_offer.label: OFFER OF VALUE
value_offer.say: Totally hear you. Even if this isn't something you need right now, I talk to vacation rental operators up and down the coast all day. Would it be worth fifteen minutes just to see what other luxury operators in similar markets are doing around inspections and turnover quality? No pitch — I just think you'd find it interesting given the standard you guys hold yourselves to.
value_offer.note: Position the meeting as valuable regardless of purchase intent. Amy cares about being best-in-class. Appeal to that identity — 'gold standard' operators want to know what other gold standard operators are doing.

redirect_to_meeting.label: REDIRECT TO MEETING
redirect_to_meeting.say: That's honestly way better to cover on a screen share where I can show you — kind of hard to do justice on a cold call. Would you have fifteen minutes this week? I can walk you through exactly how it works with your setup.
redirect_to_meeting.note: Don't get into pricing or deep technical details on a cold call. Redirect every time to the meeting where you can demo and control the conversation.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome — I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up. How does Tuesday at 11 AM look for you?
book_meeting.note: Pick a specific day and time. Don't say 'when works for you' — that creates decision fatigue. If she counters, take it immediately.

book_meeting_next_week.label: BOOK NEXT WEEK
book_meeting_next_week.say: Totally works — how about next Wednesday at 10? Or is afternoon better for you?
book_meeting_next_week.note: Stay flexible but always propose a specific time. Lock it in. Don't let it drift to 'I'll get back to you.'

meeting_booked.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — I'll send over a calendar invite right now so it's locked in. Really appreciate you taking my call, Amy. Talk to you then.
meeting_booked.note: Send the invite WHILE ON THE PHONE. Then stop selling. Don't add 'one more thing.' End warm and clean. Log the call and prep a personalized agenda before the meeting.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll shoot something over today. One quick question so it's actually useful and not just another generic pitch — what would be most relevant to you? Is it more the inspection side, the integration piece with OwnerRez, or how it works at your scale?
send_email.note: Asking what to include gives you intel AND shows you'll personalize. Whatever she says, build the email around that one thing. Always include a specific meeting time suggestion in the email.

branches.label: She tells you what to focus on

send_email_confirm.label: CONFIRM EMAIL
send_email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll put that together and get it over today. What's the best email — is it the reservations@iopescapes one, or do you have a direct one?
send_email_confirm.note: Try for a direct email. If she gives the general inbox, that's fine — but ask. Mention you'll include a couple time slots in case she wants to hop on a quick call after reading.

branches.label: Use the website one / general inbox

email_end.label: EMAIL WRAP-UP
email_end.say: Perfect — keep an eye out for it this afternoon. I'll toss in a couple time options in case you want to hop on a quick call after looking it over. Appreciate your time, Amy.
email_end.note: Send within 2 hours max. Subject line should reference this call: 'Amy — following up from our call (inspection workflow)'. Build the email around exactly what she asked for. Follow up by phone in 3-4 business days if no reply.

referral.label: REFERRAL — WRONG PERSON
referral.say: Makes total sense — you're more on the systems and booking side. Who on your team actually owns the inspection and turnover quality piece day to day? Would that be Jeremy, or someone else?
referral.note: Dropping Jeremy's name shows you've done homework and makes it easy for Amy to confirm or redirect. If she says Trish Clark (property ops manager), that's also a strong lead. Get a name AND a way to reach them.

branches.label: Not sure / we all pitch in

referral_get_name.label: GET THE REFERRAL
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — would you mind if I reached out to them directly? If I can get a direct number or email, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands instead of getting lost in the general inbox.
referral_get_name.note: If she gives you Jeremy's or Trish's contact, you now have an internal referral from a co-owner. That's gold. When you call them, open with 'Hey, Amy mentioned you'd be the right person to talk to about this.'

branches.label: Just use the main line / I'll pass it along

referral_thank.label: THANK FOR REFERRAL
referral_thank.say: Really appreciate that, Amy. I'll reach out to them and mention we spoke. Thanks for your time — enjoy the rest of your day.
referral_thank.note: Call the referral ASAP — same day. Open with Amy's name as the referral. Warm intros decay fast.

graceful_end.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_end.say: Totally understand. If anything changes — especially as you guys keep growing that portfolio — I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time, Amy.
graceful_end.note: Don't burn the bridge. Log the call, set a 60-90 day follow-up reminder. They're adding properties fast — what's not a priority at 64 homes could be critical at 80. Also consider reaching out to Jeremy or Trish directly as a separate contact.
